occurrences.line_text: The Porter opened vnto them streight way:
For streight & narrow was the way, which he did show.
And with streight diet tame his stubborne malady.
Or streight way on that last long voyage fare,
I bounden am streight after this emprize,
When armes he swore, and streight did enterpris
That streight against that knight his speare he did addresse.
But when he heard him speake, streight way he knew
Streight downe againe her selfe in great despight
Streight at his foot in base humilitee,
And her streight legs most brauely were embayld
My Lord (quoth he) me sent, and streight behight
That when the varlet heard and saw, streight way
That streight on ground made him full low to lye;
She to her vse returnd, and streight defyde
Streight gan he him reuile, and bitter rate,
That streight did lead to Plutoes griesly raine:
Soone as he entred was, the dore streight way
Who with his wisedom won, him streight did choose
With whom she marched streight against her foes,
Those could he well direct and streight as line,
And grudge, in so streight prison to be prest,
And streight they saw the raging surges reard
Which Guyon hearing, streight his Palmer bad,
Streight way he with his vertuous staffe them strooke,
And streight of beasts they comely men became;
Gan coyne streight lawes to curb their liberty;
Streight way with dreames, and with fantasticke sight
And euer what she did, was streight vndonne.
But the streight course of heauenly destiny,
It forth she cald, and gaue it streight in charge,
Who seeing her gan streight vpstart, and thought
Fell streight to ground in great astonishment;
Into his hart attonce: streight did he hayle
Where streight embraced, she to him did cry,
And an earth-quake, as if it streight would lose
So soone as they were in, the dore streight way
But lo, they streight were vanisht all and some,
And rising vp, gan streight to ouerlooke,
Streight entring into Triamond, him fild
And starting vp, streight for his armour sought:
Streight into griefe, that her deare hart nigh swelt,
She to him ran, and him with streight embras
Streight forth issewd a Knight all arm'd to proofe,
He kend it streight, and to me opened wide.
So in I past, and streight he closd the gate.
Yet since she saw the streight extremitie,
He graunted it: and streight his warrant made,
So home with her she streight the virgin lad,
No sooner sayd, but streight he after sent
And streight at him with all his force did go.
And offred streight the Lady to be slaine.
And with that word him strooke, that streight he did expire.
And streight him selfe vnto the fight addrest,
Into the floud: streight leapt the Carle vnblest,
He answered, that he would try it streight,
But streight the winged words out of his ballaunce flew.
And streight that boaster prayd, with whom he rid,
Streight way so soone as both together met,
And to my brother did ellope streight way:
Descried streight; who all the citty warned,
She bad that streight the gates should be vnbard,
Goe streight, and take with thee, to witnesse it,
The Damzell streight obayd, and putting all
So he them streight conducted to his Lord,
Of strong compulsion, and streight violence,
But streight her selfe did dight, and armor don;
But if the least appear'd, her eyes she streight reprieued.
They seeing that, let driue at him streight way,
Streight was the passage like a ploughed ridge,
And gaping greedy wide, did streight deuoure
And caused streight a Trumpet loud to shrill,
Began the streight conditions to propound,
Thenceforth she streight into a bowre him brought,
Sir Artegall, to whom she streight did hie
She weened streight, it was her Paynim Knight,
Streight downe she ranne, like an enraged cow,
Vnder Alcides club, streight tooke his flight
But ryding streight vnder the Castle wall,
To whom when tydings thereof came, he streight
And entraunce wonne. Streight th'other fled away,
But opening streight the Sparre, forth to him came,
As if he would haue ouerrun him streight,
Downe streight to ground fell his astonisht steed,
Which being shew'd, he gan him selfe streight way
And streight went forth his gladnesse to partake
Who hauing left Mercilla, streight way went
That it to such a streight mote you constraine)
But Burbon streight dismounting from his steed,
He all his forces streight to him did reare,
Willing him wend vnto the Tyrant streight,
For he had giuen streight commaundement,
But gan him streight to buckle to the fight,
Who streight her leading with meete maiestie
Hard by a streight there stands a castle strong,
By reason of the streight, and rocks among,
Of one loud crying, which they streight way ghest,
His heart gan faint, and streight he tooke his flight
Thereof full blyth the Lady streight became,
Well weend he streight, that he should be the same,
But gaue them streight vnto that Squire againe,
That he streight way with haughtie choler burned,
And with presumpteous powre against that knight streight go'th.
Whereof he taking oddes, streight bids him dight
To whose wise read she hearkning, sent me streight
Streight to the carkasse of that Knight he went,
The groome went streight way in, and to his Lord
And running streight into the thickest wood,
Would streight dislodge the wretched wearie life.
And streight his combrous armes aside did lay
In streight obseruaunce of religious vow,
They stayd not there, but streight way in did pas.
From his deuotion streight he troubled was;
Pursu'd him streight, in mynd to bene ywroken
And running streight vpon that villaine base,
Whom them perceiuing, streight to him obayd,
Tho all in rage, he on him streight did seaze,
But streight he held his hand at his commaundement.
So vp he rose, and forth streight way he went
And needs with him streight to the place would ryde,
Therefore a Iurie was impaneld streight,
The Prince assented, and then he streight way
But being checkt, he did abstaine streight way,
And catching vp his arms streight to the noise forth past.
And streight vnto her litle flocke did fare:
To him, the Shepheard streight with iealousie did frize.
And willed streight the slaues should forth be called,
With which he streight went to the Captaines nest.
Which she streight way for dread least, if her syre
Which well auizing, streight she gan to cast
So full of ioy, streight forth she ran in hast
And gan to question streight how she it knew.
Himselfe in streighter bandes too rash implyes,
Giue him more labour, and with streighter law,
So streightly God doth iudge. But gentle knight,
And streightly did embrace her body bright,
And loose affections streightly to restraine;
Ye did so streightly them a sunder keepe,
But strained him so streightly, that he chokt him neare.
Yet in the streightnesse of that captiue state,
And by her hellish science raisd streightway
And streightway sent with carefull diligence,
And pluckt him backe; who all on fire streightway,
Soone hearkned, and her painted bote streightway
Then gan Sir Calidore to ghesse streightway
Went forth streightway into the forrest wyde,
Or doen she heard, she would streightwayes inuent,
From which forth gusht a streme of gorebloud thick,
That a large purple streme adown their giambeux falles.
Adowne their sides like litle riuers stremed,
And vp to heauen his eyes fast streming threw.
Which great Alcides in Stremona slew,
And sacred Reuerence, yborne of heauenly strene,
For that same beast was bred of hellish strene,
And proou'd your strength on a strong enimie,
Deuoid of outward sense, and natiue strength,
And with extorted powre, and borrow'd strength,
Henceforth sir knight, take to you wonted strength,
If any strength we haue, it is to ill,
And haue her strength recur'd from fraile infirmitis.
And three mens strength vnto the stroke he layd;
To reaue by strength the griped gage away:
Whenas no strength, nor stroks mote him constraine
Ne weene my right with strength adowne to tread,
More huge in strength, then wise in workes he was,
As steele can wound, or strength can ouerthroe.
For when they once to perfect strength do grow,
But him in strength and skill the Prince surpast,
Of natiue strength now, that he them suruiu'd.
By strength was wielded without pollicie;
But trust vnto his strength and manhood meare,
The growing euill, ere it strength haue got,
And our weake hands (whom need new strength shall teach)
That whilest his breath did strength to him supply,
Through her maine strength, in which she most doth trust,
And now he strength gan adde vnto his will,
Both light of heauen, and strength of men relate:
Through which aduantage, in his strength he rose,
With all the strength and stifnesse that he can.
Rose in his strength, and gan her fresh assayle,
His strength still more, but she still more decrewed.
Her wounds, that vnto strength restor'd her soone anew.
And by his strength rule to himselfe did gaine
For most of strength and beautie his desire
For strength, and wealth, and happinesse she lends,
Ne former strength returne so suddenly,
That Castle was the strength of all that state,
Vntill that state by strength was pulled downe,
Besides the double strength, which in them was:
And seem'd to be of infinite great strength;
And did in strength most sorts of men surpas,
It strength to me supplies, & chears my dulled spright.
Wasting the strength of her immortall age.
By strength haue ouerthrowne a stubborne steare,
Teach him the weake to strengthen, & the stro[n]g suppresse.
Whereby his strengthes assay he might him teach.
With this sad hersall of his heauy stresse,
Who stird with pitty of the stressed plight
Whereat he gan to stretch: but he againe
Did stretch themselues without the vtmost bound
Yet doth it selfe stretch forth to heauens hight,
But th'heedfull Boateman strongly forth did stretch
Presume so high to stretch mine humble quill?
Stretch her white rod ouer the Belgicke shore,
And gan to stretch his limbs; which feeling ill
Typhoeus ioynts were stretched on a gin,
His tayle was stretched out in wondrous length,
Then gan he tosse aloft his stretched traine,
With feeble hands then stretched forth on hye,
Till they to heauens hight forth stretched bee.
But stretched forth in idlenesse alwayes,
She stretched forth a long white sclender wand.
Was stretched forth, that nigh fild all the place,
And stretching forth his hand, did often thinke
Their scepters stretcht from East to Westerne shore,
Were stretcht now forth at length without entraile.
And scaly tayle was stretcht adowne his backe full low.
Loe where your foe lyes stretcht in monstrous length,
Where stretcht he lay vpon the sunny side
Stretcht on the ground in monstrous large extent,
That stretcht it selfe into an ample plaine,
That stretcht it selfe, as it had long lyen still;
But that lame Hag, still as abroad he strew
The ruefull Strich, still waiting on the bere,
Both stricken strike, and beaten both do beat,
That to the earth him droue, as stricken dead,
Againe she stricken was with sore affright,
The stricke[n] Deare doth chalenge by the bleeding wound.
Till hauing often by him stricken beene,
Is lightly stricken with some stones throw;
They stricken were with great astonishment,
Them to haue stricken, and thrise to haue slaine.
Betwixt them both was but a litle stride,
That stopt the entraunce with his spacious stride,
A sturdy villein, striding stiffe and bold,
Henceforth his ghost freed from repining strife,
Abhorred bloudshed, and tumultuous strife,
My fearefull flesh did tremble at their strife,
I euer scornd, and ioyd to stirre vp strife,
Perswade vs die, to stint all further strife:
Through strife, and bloud-shed, and auengement,
Feare, sicknesse, age, losse, labour, sorrow, strife,
What meanest thou by this reprochfull strife?
Vnto that stead, their strife to vnderstond;
They stint their strife, and him assaile on euery side.
by Strife is rayld vpon.
And stirre him vp to strife and cruell fight.
Occasion to wrath, and cause of strife;
But Guyon, in the heat of all his strife,
To stirre vp strife, and do them disagree;
Whiles Guyon standing by, their vncouth strife does see.
Both yeeld, to stay your deadly strife a space.
Debatefull strife, and cruell enmitie
Strife; and debate, bloudshed, and bitternesse,
And fast beside him sat tumultuous Strife:
That breathed strife and troublous enmitie;
Which was their chiefe and th'author of that strife:
To stirre vp strife, and troublous contecke broch:
As smoke and sulphure mingled with confused strife.
At length allay, and stint thy stormy strife,
The bloudie battell, and to stirre vp strife,
The enimy of peace, and author of all strife.
Sith him he saw still stronger grow through strife,
Of pardon for the strife, which late befell
Emongst them was sterne Strife, and Anger stout,
So did they all their former strife accord;
Such as was Orpheus, that when strife was growen
To stirre vp strife, twixt loue and spight and ire,
To stint all strife, and foster friendly peace,
First he desir'd their cause of strife to see:
That oftentimes vnquiet strife did moue
doth their long strife agree.
Let forth his wearie ghost and made an end of strife.
And stinted all the strife incontinent.
And pacifie the strife, which causd so deadly smart.
From blouddy strife, and blessed peace to seeke,
In perfect loue, deuoide of hatefull strife,
To stirre vp strife, when most vs needeth rest,
Prince Arthur stints their strife.
He yeelded, and her tooke; so stinted all their strife.
And strife, and warre, and anger does subdew:
Which him had sought through trouble & lo[n]g strife;
Certes your strife were easie to accord,
For stint of strife, and stablishment of rest
To stirre vp strife, and many a Tragicke stowre,
Through auarice, or powre, or guile, or strife,
That haue her drawne to all this troublous strife,
To stint all strife and troublous enmitie,
Betwixt you two began this strife and sterne vprore.
As if her vitall powers were at strife
He spyde, lamenting her vnluckie strife,
Which Shepheards lead, without debate or bitter strife.
Both falling out doe stirre vp strifefull broyle,
But strifull minde, and diuerse qualitee
Her list in strifull termes with him to balke,
So all together stird vp strifull stoure,
And strike so fiercely, that they do impresse
Both stricken strike, and beaten both do beat,
Now strike your sailes ye iolly Mariners,
Or strike, or hurle, round in warelike gyre,
The law of armes, to strike foe vndefide.
And bid them strike the marke, which he had eyde,
To strike his oares, and mightily doth driue
Stout Priamond, but not so strong to strike,
He forced was to strike, and saue him selfe from teene.
Stroke him, as he his hand to strike vpreard,
Threatning to strike, vnlesse he would withstand:
And made him oft, when he would strike, forbeare;
Ne thenceforth euer strike in battell stroke,
And not well fastened, would not strike him strayt,
And as she did her selfe to strike prepare,
Full on his beuer did him strike so sore,
The whyles they strike at him with heedlesse might,
With loue, long time did languish as the striken hind.
Attonce he wards and strikes, he takes and payes,
Strikes in the stocke, ne thence can be rel[e]ast,
The Parthian strikes a stag with shiuering dart,
Strikes at an Heron with all his bodies sway,
But strikes his sayles, and vereth his mainsheat,
But now a while let downe that haughtie string,
And.strooke so strongly, that the knotty string
Had riuen bene, and all her hart strings brast,
Ne spared they to strip her naked all.
Some whet their kniues, and strip their elboes bare:
But when he could not quite it, with one stripe
A handsome stripling with great crueltee,
But cleard that stripling of th'imputed blame,
and strips Duessa quight.
Another her out boastes, and all for tryall strips.
They were faire Ladies, till they fondly striu'd
Greeting his graue: his grudging ghost did striue
Where long remaining, he did alwaies striue
Who then can striue with strong necessitie,
And striue your excellent selfe to excell;
To tell, were as to striue against the streame.
striue her to banish cleane.
Ne certes Sir striue you it to withstand,
Still did they striue, and dayly disagree;
When they would striue dew reason to exceed;
Yet both doe striue their fearfulnesse to faine.
And striue to passe (as she could well enough)
But euery one did striue his fellow downe to throw.
For which ye men do striue: few get, but many mis.
Nought booted it the Paynim then to striue;
With these in praise of pollicies mote striue.
Then he with all his puissance doth striue
But after the foule foster Timias did striue.
Against it strongly striue, and yield thee not,
But after when both nations gan to striue,
But shame of all, that doe for honor striue,
And each did striue the other to out-goe,
For which the three faire Goddesses did striue:
All mindlesse of the Golden fleece, which made them striue.
Why do ye striue for Ladies loue so sore,
That striue and storme with stirre outrageous,
To moderate stiffe minds, disposd to striue:
And being dead in vaine yet many striue:
As two fierce Buls, that striue the rule to get
The Ladies for the Girdle striue
And rend a sunder quite, if he thereto list striue.
So chast and loyall liu'd, but she would striue
Whereof I glad did not gainesay nor striue,
Whylest euerie one with helping hands did striue
Did striue to match with strong contention,
So th'one for wrong, the other striues for right:
So th'one for wrong, the other striues for right,
And striues to mount vnto his natiue seat;
As he that striues to stop a suddein flood,
Paridell for her striues,
Yet still he striues, ne any perill spares,
As raging flames who striueth to suppresse.
All striuing to infixe their feeble stings,
Striuing to loose the knot, that fast him tyes,
And ouer him, art striuing to compaire
The carefull seruant, striuing with his raging Lord.
So striuing each th'other to vndermine,
And striuing, fit to make, I feare do marre:
So striuing each did other more augment,
Striuing to comfort him all that they can,
Striuing in vaine to rere him selfe vpright.
two brethren that doe strive,
From heaping stroakes, which thereon soused sore:
And perill without show: therefore your stroke
The stroke down fro[m]; her head vnto her shoulder glaunst.
Astonied with the stroke of their owne hand,
So hugely stroke, that it the steele did riue,
Therewith vpon his crest he stroke him so,
High minded Cleopatra, that with stroke
That th'onely breath him daunts, who hath escapt the stroke.
The idle stroke, enforcing furious way,
Stroke one of those deformed heads so sore,
The stroke vpon his shield so heauie lites,
And threatning high his dreadfull stroke did see,
But th'idle stroke yet backe recoyld in vaine,
And three mens strength vnto the stroke he layd;
With which he stroke so furious and so fell,
The knight was wrath to see his stroke beguyld,
And him so strongly stroke, that to the ground him feld.
They gan abstaine from dint of direfull stroke,
Him first saluted with a sturdy stroke;
And much ashamd, that stroke of liuing arme
Vnder Sir Guyons puissaunt stroke to fall,
Through many a stroke, & many a streaming wound,
And doubling all his powres, redoubled euery stroke.
The stroke thereof from entrance may defend;
That direfull stroke thou dearely shalt aby.
Yet with his troncheon he so rudely stroke
His hand relented, and the stroke forbore,
And on the hauberk stroke the Prince so sore,
He stroke so hugely with his borrowd blade,
But when he stroke most strong, the dint deceiu'd,
All suddenly with mortall stroke astownd,
Through heauy stroke of Britomartis hond.
That stroke the hardy Squire did sore displease,
But ere the stroke could seize his aymed place,
He was dismayd, and thrise his breast he stroke,
He fell halfe dead; next stroke him should haue slaine,
Who with the sudden stroke astonisht sore,
The dreadfull stroke in case it had arriued,
He stroke, he soust, he foynd, he hewd, he lasht,
Stroke him, as he his hand to strike vpreard,
Yet still that direfull stroke kept on his way,
For that with puissant stroke she downe did beare
And therewith stroke at her so hideouslie,
The wicked stroke vpon her helmet chaunst,
Nathelesse she full of wrath for that late stroke,
That yet of mortall stroke the stound doth beare.
The puissance of his intended stroke.
Ne thenceforth euer strike in battell stroke,
Had not the noble Prince his readie stroke represt.
And stroke the Pagan with his steely brand
Ne can be cured of that cruell stroke
And at one stroke cropt off her head with scorne,
And rudely stroke at him on euery side:
Dismayd so with the stroke, that he no colours knew.
Such an huge stroke, that it of sence distraught her:
Of that sad stroke, that halfe enrag'd she grew,
Nath'lesse that stroke so cruell passage found,
She with one stroke both head and helmet cleft.
In hope some stroke to fasten on him neare;
That one sure stroke he might vnto him reach,
The wicked stroke did wound his enemy,
And euer ere he saw the stroke to land,
Ere that huge stroke arriued on him neare,
Yet was the stroke so forcibly applide,
So was he stound with stroke of her huge taile.
Vnder his stroke he to him stepping neare,
Yet the huge stroke, which he before intended,
He stroke him with Chrysaor on the hed,
That neither could the others stroke sustaine,
Preuented him before his stroke could light,
His stroke redoubled with such might and maine,
And with his speare strooke me one stroke or twaine;
Tempred so well, but more admyr'd the stroke
No more then for the stroke of strawes or bents:
But to him stepping, such a stroke him lent,
And with the second stroke, thought certainely
For ere his stroke attayned his intent,
Albe the stroke so strong and puissant were,
Rather then let my selfe of wight be stroken,
And doubled strokes, like dreaded thunders threat:
With heaped strokes more hugely, then before,
But Satyrane with strokes him turning, staid,
But with outrageous strokes did him restraine,
Ne ought his sturdie strokes might stand afore,
They heapt huge strokes, the scorned life to quell,
With strokes of mortall steele without remorse,
Through wounds, & strokes, & stubborne handeling,
Their mightie strokes their haberieons dismayld,
With hideous strokes, and importable powre,
Their strokes did raine, yet did he neuer quaile,
Now to Pyrrochles many strokes he told;
Gan heap huge strokes on him, as ere he downe was cast.
Ne ought the more their mightie strokes surceasse,
But with her dreadfull strokes were all dismayd:
And oftentimes loud strokes, and ringing sounds
And with huge strokes, and cruell battery
Yet he perforce him held, and strokes vpon him hept.
Full many mightie strokes on either side
Full many strokes, that mortally were ment,
With heapes of strokes, which he at him let flie,
Strokes, wounds, wards, weapons, all they did despise,
Instead of strokes, each other kissed glad,
But none of them against his strokes could stand,
So dreadfull were his strokes, so deadly was his hond.
All which at once huge strokes on him did pound,
And shun his mightie strokes, gainst which no armes auayled.
Heaping huge strokes, as thicke as showre of hayle,
With dreadfull strokes let driue at him so sore,
The hideous noise of their huge strokes did heare,
So dreadfull strokes each did at other driue,
And thundred strokes thereon so hideouslie,
So terribly his dreadfull strokes did thonder,
What strokes, what dreadfull stoure it stird this day:
And heaped strokes so fast on euery side,
With bitter strokes it both began, and ended.
With huge redoubled strokes she on him layd;
Ne either sought the others strokes to shun,
And their huge strokes full daungerously bestow,
He shund his strokes, where euer they did fall,
